newsitem.title: UK: Japanese cities most expensive for expats - survey.
newsitem.headline: Japanese cities most expensive for expats - survey.

text.p: Tokyo is still the world's most expensive city for expatriates to live in but a weaker yen means costs are falling for foreigners, according to a survey published on Wednesday.
The most expensive European city, Oslo, is ranked behind second-placed Osaka and Kobe, the Economist Intelligence Unit's Worldwide Cost of Living survey said.
West European cities in general, with London being a notable exception, continue to become cheaper places in which to live, due to a stronger U.S. dollar and weaker local currencies.
London has risen strongly in the rankings, moving from 29th position a year ago to 14 in June, 1997. This is largely because of high interest rates and confidence in the pound sterling.
Other cities where costs for expatriates are on the rise are Dublin, up to 28 from 35, and Moscow, rising to fourth place from 10th a year ago.
The Swiss cities of Geneva and Zurich, traditionally the most expensive in Europe, have fallen in the rankings from fifth to 10th and from third to sixth, respectively.
Hong Kong (5), Singapore (9), Taipei (11) and Beijing (16), have all become more expensive, moving up in the rankings as European cities have slipped down.
East European cities remain among the 20 cheapest cities in which to live in the world. Surprisingly, perhaps, it costs about the same to live in Prague as in Johannesburg.
The cities are measured against the cost of living in New York, which this year is the 22nd most expensive place to live.
The top 10 placings in the EIU's survey are as follows, with last year's ranking in brackets: 1. Tokyo (1) 2. Osaka-Kobe (2) 3. Oslo (4) 4. Moscow (10) 5. Hong Kong (12) 6. Libreville (10)
